children.full: Details the way in which the text of the constitution can be formally amended. This is distinct from the task of constitutional interpretation often undertaken by courts.
children.name: Constitution amendment procedure

children.full: Some provisions in the constitutions may be so fundamental to the constitutional order, or so politically contentious, that they are designated as unamendable. In such cases, unamendable provisions are expressly noted in the constitution.
children.name: Unamendable provisions

children.full: The steps that the government must follow to gain approval for accession to a treaty. Commonly this involves gaining the consent of part or all of the legislature.
children.name: Treaty ratification

children.full: This especially concerns the status of treaties with regard to the constitution or ordinary law, and determines whether treaties are superior or inferior to the constitution or ordinary law.
children.name: Legal status of treaties

children.full: Reference to international law, including treaties, agreements, norms, or other commitments.
children.name: International law

children.full: Reference to international organizations, whether generally or with regard to specific international organizations such as the United Nations.
children.name: International organizations

children.full: Reference to customary international law, the law of nations, or the generally accepted principles of international law.
children.name: Customary international law

children.full: Establishes the bodies competent to nominate and approve members of the cabinet. Appointment is usually made by the executive branch, and is in some cases subject to approval by the legislative branch.
children.name: Cabinet selection

children.full: Cabinet members generally serve at the pleasure of the appointing power, typically the executive. Many constitutions also allow the legislative branch to remove cabinet members in cases of misconduct.
children.name: Cabinet removal

children.full: Matters on which the executive’s ministers have the power to act. These powers are often expressed in very general terms, but in some cases additional powers are enumerated for exercise in particular contexts.
children.name: Powers of cabinet

children.full: Qualifications that an individual must meet in order to serve in the cabinet. This is sometimes as simple as eligibility to vote, but may include a number of requirements. Ministers may also be restricted from serving as legislators.
children.name: Eligibility for cabinet
Cabinet
children.full: The body of high ranking officials who act as the heads of government departments and advise the head of state or head of government.
Distinguishes the structure of the executive. Establishes the offices of head of state and/or head of government.
children.name: Name/structure of executive(s)

children.full: Specification of the deputy to the head of state or head of government. The deputy executive typically has the power to act when the executive is absent or becomes incapable of holding office.
children.name: Deputy executive

children.full: The procedure through which a candidate for the office of head of state is nominated and approved. While there is great variation, common procedures include heredity, direct election, or election by the legislature.
children.name: Head of state selection

children.full: Qualifications that an individual must meet in order to serve as the head of government. This is sometimes as simple as eligibility to vote, but may include a number of requirements.
children.name: Eligibility for head of state

children.full: In cases where the head of state has committed a crime, or lost the confidence of the legislature, he or she may be removed from office. This may be carried out by the legislature, the head of government, or another competent body.
children.name: Head of state removal

children.full: The minimum age that an individual must have attained before assuming the office of head of state.
children.name: Minimum age of head of state

children.full: Protection, whether absolute or limited, against prosecution for the head of state. This may involve protection against prosecution for certain kinds of crimes, or for a specified period of time.
children.name: Head of state immunity

children.full: The number of terms, either consecutive or in total, that an individual may serve in the office of head of state
children.name: Head of state term limits

children.full: Allows the head of state to enact rules without following the usual channels for the passage of legislation. This power is usually limited to particular circumstances or areas of government activity.
children.name: Head of state decree power

children.full: In addition to a cabinet, other councils of high ranking officials may advise the head of state. This could include a privy council to a monarch, for example. Some advisory bodies may consult on specific topics, such as national security.
children.name: Advisory bodies to the head of state

children.full: Gives a body within the executive branch the authority to overrule a criminal conviction.
children.name: Power to pardon

children.full: Cabinet members generally serve at the pleasure of the appointing power, typically the executive. Many constitutions also allow the legislative branch to remove cabinet members in cases of misconduct.
children.name: Cabinet removal

children.full: Matters on which the executive’s ministers have the power to act. These powers are often expressed in very general terms, but in some cases additional powers are enumerated for exercise in particular contexts.
children.name: Powers of cabinet

children.full: Establishes ultimate control of the state's armed forces. Usually the head of state or head of government. This may be a ceremonial role, or may involve significant decision-making power.
children.name: Designation of commander in chief

children.full: Qualifications that an individual must meet in order to serve in the cabinet. This is sometimes as simple as eligibility to vote, but may include a number of requirements. Ministers may also be restricted from serving as legislators.
children.name: Eligibility for cabinet

children.full: In cases where the head of state has committed a crime, or lost the confidence of the legislature, he or she may be removed from office. This may be carried out by the legislature, the head of government, or another competent body.
children.name: Head of state removal

children.full: In cases where the head of government has committed a crime, or lost the confidence of the legislature, he or she may be removed from office. This may be carried out by the legislature, the head of state, or another competent body.
children.name: Head of government removal

children.full: Allows the head of state to enact rules without following the usual channels for the passage of legislation. This power is usually limited to particular circumstances or areas of government activity.
children.name: Head of state decree power

children.full: Specific, enumerated powers that are given to the head of government. For example, some heads of government are given the power to issue currency, grant asylum, award decorations, or various other particular powers.
children.name: Head of government powers

children.full: Allows the head of government, or exceptionally the cabinet, to enact rules without following the usual channels for the passage of legislation. This power is usually limited to particular circumstances or areas of government activity.
children.name: Head of government decree power

children.full: Protection, whether absolute or limited, against prosecution for the head of government. This may involve protection against prosecution for certain kinds of crimes, or for a specified period of time.
children.name: Head of government immunity

children.full: Allows the government to declare an exceptional state, such as emergency, siege, or martial law. Usually gives the government additional powers, and may suspend some normal functions of the political system.
children.name: Emergency provisions

children.full: Establishes ultimate control of the state's armed forces. Usually the head of state or head of government. This may be a ceremonial role, or may involve significant decision-making power.
children.name: Designation of commander in chief

children.full: The selection process for the highest ranking officers in the military. This often involves appointment by the head of the executive branch, and in some cases also requires the approval of at least part of the legislature.
children.name: Selection of active-duty commanders

children.full: A duty to serve a specified period of time in the country's military. Often also includes protections for conscientious objectors.
children.name: Duty to serve in the military

children.full: Limitations either on the government's use of the military, or on the actions of members of the military. For example, prohibition of domestic deployment of the military, or restrictions on the political rights of military officers.
children.name: Restrictions on the armed forces

children.full: Courts with jurisdiction limited to charges against members of the military, and tasked with enforcing military law.
children.name: Establishment of military courts

children.full: Terrorism specifically mentioned, usually in the context of the criminal justice system, or with regard to the activities of the military or other public safety bodies.
children.name: Terrorism

children.full: Qualifications that an individual must meet in order to serve as the minister of defense. Particularly concerned with whether the minister is required to be, or prohibited from being, a member of the military.
children.name: Restrictions on minister of defense

children.full: In cases where the head of government has committed a crime, or lost the confidence of the legislature, he or she may be removed from office. This may be carried out by the legislature, the head of state, or another competent body.
children.name: Head of government removal

children.full: Specific, enumerated powers that are given to the head of government. For example, some heads of government are given the power to issue currency, grant asylum, award decorations, or various other particular powers.
children.name: Head of government powers

children.full: Establishes whether the head of government is required to serve, or is prohibited from serving, as a member of the legislature.
children.name: Head of government's role in the legislature

children.full: The procedure by which the head of government is replaced in the event that he or she does not complete his or her term. This might involve a predetermined succession, or reversion to the normal selection procedure.
children.name: Head of government replacement

children.full: Qualifications that an individual must meet in order to serve as the head of government. This is sometimes as simple as eligibility to vote, but may include a number of requirements.
children.name: Eligibility for head of government

children.full: Allows the head of government, or exceptionally the cabinet, to enact rules without following the usual channels for the passage of legislation. This power is usually limited to particular circumstances or areas of government activity.
children.name: Head of government decree power

children.full: The minimum age that an individual must have attained before assuming the office of head of government.
children.name: Minimum age of head of government

children.full: Protection, whether absolute or limited, against prosecution for the head of government. This may involve protection against prosecution for certain kinds of crimes, or for a specified period of time.
children.name: Head of government immunity

children.full: The number of years that a head of government serves before either reappointment or dismissal is required.
children.name: Head of government term length

children.full: The number of terms, either consecutive or in total, that an individual may serve in the office of head of government.
children.name: Head of government term limits

children.full: Procedures for removing individual members of the legislature for crimes or malfeasance. In some cases this action is taken by the legislator's chamber.
children.name: Removal of individual legislators

children.full: Specifies who has the authority to dismiss the legislature. May also specify the conditions under which this may take place.
children.name: Dismissal of the legislature

children.full: Establishes the procedure through which a seat in the legislature may be filled in the event that a legislator has been removed from office, resigns, or dies.
children.name: Replacement of legislators

children.full: Procedures for removing individual members of the legislature for crimes or malfeasance. In some cases this action is taken by the legislator's chamber.
children.name: Removal of individual legislators

children.full: Specifies who has the authority to dismiss the legislature. May also specify the conditions under which this may take place.
children.name: Dismissal of the legislature

children.full: Allows the legislature to take additional steps to pass legislation that has been vetoed by the actor responsible for approving or rejecting legislation. This typically requires a supermajority, but there is some variation.
children.name: Veto override procedure

children.full: Establishes the procedure through which a seat in the legislature may be filled in the event that a legislator has been removed from office, resigns, or dies.
children.name: Replacement of legislators

children.full: Specifies who has the power to propose new legislation. Beyond members of the legislature, this may or may not be extended to political parties, the general public, the head of government, or the head of state.
children.name: Initiation of general legislation

children.full: Allows the legislature to take additional steps to pass legislation that has been vetoed by the actor responsible for approving or rejecting legislation. This typically requires a supermajority, but there is some variation.
children.name: Veto override procedure

children.full: Particularly vital or contentious policy areas may require a supermajority of a specified size in order to pass legislation.  Although constitutional amendments often require a supermajority, this topic addresses ordinary legislation only.
children.name: Supermajority required for legislation

children.full: The number of years that a representative in the first chamber of the legislature serves before reelection, reappointment, or dismissal is required.
children.name: Term length for first chamber

children.full: Names the office that presides over the first chamber of the legislature. This function might be fulfilled by the head of government, a member of the chamber, the deputy executive, or another official.
children.name: Leader of first chamber

children.full: Qualifications that an individual must meet in order to serve as a representative in the first chamber of the legislature. These often concern residency, proficiency in the official language, or prior occupation.
children.name: Eligibility for first chamber

children.full: The minimum age that an individual must have attained to be eligible to serve as a representative in the first chamber of the legislature.
children.name: Minimum age for first chamber

children.full: The total number of seats in the first chamber of the legislature.
children.name: Size of first chamber

children.full: Names specific areas of legislation that are a special concern for the first chamber. This may include sole authority to legislate in these areas.
children.name: First chamber reserved policy areas

children.full: Specifies the proportion of the seats in the first chamber that must be assigned to representatives of a particular group, such as women, ethnic groups, political parties, religious groups, or social classes.
children.name: First chamber representation quotas

children.full: The number of terms, either consecutive or in total, that an individual may serve as a representative in the first chamber of the legislature.
children.name: Term limits for first chamber

children.full: Establishes who has the authority to call an extraordinary session of the legislature, and in some cases what circumstances would allow them to take such action.
children.name: Extraordinary legislative sessions

children.full: May bar legislators from engaging in other occupations during their term in office. Limitations might include prohibitions on holding some or all other public offices, or engaging in private business.
children.name: Outside professions of legislators

children.full: The legislature is only permitted to conduct its business, especially to vote on legislation, when a certain percentage of its members are present.
children.name: Quorum for legislative sessions

children.full: The number of days or months that the legislature meets within a year.
children.name: Length of legislative sessions

children.full: Requires legislators to attend sessions or votes. Examples include mandatory attendance, punishment after a specified number of absences, or delegating the matter to ordinary law.
children.name: Attendance by legislators

children.full: Requires that a written record of the deliberations of the legislature be published.
children.name: Publication of deliberations

children.full: Establishes the level of transparency in legislative voting. This could be a matter of public record, always kept secret, or varied depending on the topic of the vote.
children.name: Secrecy of legislative votes

children.full: Special legislative processes for budget bills, which may include restrictions on proposal, approval, or amendment. Budget bills refer to legislation that lays out the revenues and expenditures for some period of time, usually in years.
children.name: Budget bills

children.full: Special legislative processes for tax bills, which may include restrictions on proposal, approval, or amendment. Tax bills refer to legislation specifically for collecting revenue for public use, usually in the form of taxes or tariffs.
children.name: Tax bills

children.full: Special legislative processes for finance bills, which may include restrictions on proposal, approval, or amendment. Finance bills refer to legislation specifically for the borrowing of money for governmental use, like loans from NGOs, other countries, or even private individuals.
children.name: Finance bills

children.full: Special legislative processes for spending bills, which may include restrictions on proposal, approval, or amendment. Spending bills refer to legislation specifically for the expenditure of government money.
children.name: Spending bills

children.full: Mention of national economic plans, possibly with the procedure for establishing them. Such procedures may include special rules for proposal, approval, or amendment.
children.name: Economic plans

children.full: Special legislative processes for organic laws, which may include restrictions on proposal, approval, or amendment. Organic laws establish fundamental aspects of the constitutional order, including establishing institutions like the courts or legislature, and in some jurisdictions are accorded similar status to the constitution itself. They sometimes require a higher standard for approval than ordinary law.
children.name: Organic laws

children.full: Describes the procedure through which members of the second chamber of the legislature are elected or appointed. This is often different from the selection procedure used for the first chamber.
children.name: Second chamber selection

children.full: Names the office that presides over the second chamber of the legislature. This function might be fulfilled by a member of the chamber, the deputy executive, or another official.
children.name: Leader of second chamber

children.full: Qualifications that an individual must meet in order to serve as a representative in the second chamber of the legislature. These often concern residency, proficiency in the official language, or prior occupation.
children.name: Eligibility for second chamber

children.full: The number of years that a representative in the second chamber of the legislature serves before reelection, reappointment, or dismissal is required.
children.name: Term length of second chamber

children.full: The total number of seats in the second chamber of the legislature.
children.name: Size of second chamber

children.full: Names specific areas of legislation that are a special concern for the first chamber. This may include sole authority to legislate in these areas.
children.name: Second chamber reserved policy areas

children.full: The number of terms, either consecutive or in total, that an individual may serve as a representative in the second chamber of the legislature.
children.name: Term limits of second chamber

children.full: Describes the principal features of the national flag.
children.name: National flag

children.full: Names the official anthem of the state.
children.name: National anthem

children.full: Names the capital city of the state.
children.name: National capital

children.full: Affirms the national motto, sometimes in more than one language.
children.name: National motto

children.full: A description of the system of government that the constitution is intended to create. Could be a description of the structure of the state, or of the political system.
children.name: Type of government envisioned

children.full: Requires certain public office holders to take an oath to support or abide by the constitution.
children.name: Oaths to abide by constitution

children.full: Establishes the agent with the authority to install the constitution or from which the state derives its ultimate authority. Many constitutions invoke the people, an assembly, a group of subnational units, a monarch, or a deity.
children.name: Source of constitutional authority

children.full: Reference to science, which may include prioritization of investment in scientific research, or mandate state support for science and innovation.
children.name: Reference to science

children.full: Considered one of the fundamental values of many states. Often mentioned in the preamble as a motivation for the constitution.
children.name: Reference to fraternity/solidarity

children.full: Reference to a group of states, a geographical region, or an intergovernmental organization, such as the European Union.
children.name: Regional group(s)

children.full: Mention of territory beyond the national borders that is under the government's control. This may include colonies, protectorates, or territories.
children.name: Colonies

children.full: Reference to historical figures or political theorists. Usually mentioned in the preamble in the context of a particular political tradition.
children.name: Political theorists/figures

children.full: Usually in the context of specifying the new regime's treatment of these crimes. May grant amnesty or require punishment.
children.name: Crimes of the previous regime

children.full: Protects individuals and businesses from government confiscation of their property without proper compensation. The level of compensation may be variously specified as fair, full, appropriate, adequate, or otherwise.
children.name: Protection from expropriation

children.full: Allows individuals and corporations the sole ownership of real property, effects, financial instruments, or other objects. This right is in some cases open to violation in the interests of the community.
children.name: Right to own property

children.full: Grants individuals the freedom to choose their occupation and their place of employment without interference from the government.
children.name: Right to choose occupation

children.full: Grants individuals the right to establish for-profit commercial endeavors.
children.name: Right to establish a business

children.full: Gives individuals and businesses the exclusive right to protect and profit from their creative works.
children.name: Provisions for intellectual property

children.full: Protects individuals and businesses from monopolies, price fixing, and other means of reducing competition in the marketplace.
children.name: Right to competitive marketplace

children.full: Forbids the state from treating individuals in a way that offends the principle of human dignity. This may include forms of corporal or capital punishment, excessive delays in assessing punishment, or other actions prejudicial to the rights of offenders.
children.name: Prohibition of cruel treatment

children.full: Forbids the state from torturing individuals, and in some cases from using coerced statements in court.  This prohibition may be limited in cases of war or other circumstances.
children.name: Prohibition of torture

children.full: Establishes a right to life. The precise meaning of this provision varies between jurisdictions, and may or may not be a reference to the unborn.
children.name: Right to life

children.full: Forbids the practice of owning or otherwise exploiting human beings. May still allow for compulsory labor as a punishment for a crime, and/or compulsory service in the military in time of war.
children.name: Prohibition of slavery

children.full: Forbids the state from employing the death penalty as a punishment for any crime.
children.name: Prohibition of capital punishment

children.full: Forbids the state from inflicting physical harm on an offender as a punishment for any crime.
children.name: Prohibition of corporal punishment

children.full: Grants individuals the right to express their thoughts and feelings without prior censorship or other forms of governmental interference. This right is rarely absolute, and is often limited in cases of sedition, hate speech, or obscenity.
children.name: Freedom of expression

children.full: Grants individuals the right to hold religious beliefs, and to freely practice those religious beliefs. This right is also commonly understood to include the right to change one's religion, or to have no religion at all.
children.name: Freedom of religion

children.full: Grants individuals the right to form groups or associations for any otherwise legal purpose. This also sometimes includes the right not to join or associate with a group.
children.name: Freedom of association

children.full: Grants individuals the right to gather in groups, in public spaces, for any otherwise legal purpose. This is right is closely associated with the idea of protest.
children.name: Freedom of assembly

children.full: Grants citizens the right to travel and reside anywhere within the state, and to travel to and from other countries. The right does not normally grant non-citizens access to the state.
children.name: Freedom of movement

children.full: Grants individuals protection against government intrusion into their property, papers, person, or communications without proper authorization. Also protects against such intrusions by private individuals.
children.name: Right to privacy

children.full: Grants individuals the right to believe or think anything they find compelling. This does not necessarily mean that they have a right to express these beliefs.
children.name: Freedom of opinion/thought/conscience

children.full: The right to vote is held by all citizens. There may nevertheless be some restrictions on voting by residency, age, residency or criminal conviction.
children.name: Claim of universal suffrage

children.full: Children are guaranteed certain rights or afforded special protections, which may include state-provided education and healthcare, and/or the right to be free from any kind of abuse.
children.name: Rights of children guaranteed

children.full: Grants groups and individuals the right to bring petitions to the government. This includes the right to bring complaints about the actions of the government.
children.name: Right of petition

children.full: Grants individuals the right to commit to one another and raise children together. This right is closely tied to the right to marry. Many constitutions stipulate only a general state duty to protect the family.
children.name: Right to found a family

children.full: Grants individuals access to information collected or held by the government, particularly information about oneself, or information of general public interest.
children.name: Right to information

children.full: Grants adults the right to enter into a legally recognized, long-term commitment to one another. This may include a definition of marriage, and may or may not be limited to heterosexual couples.
children.name: Right to marry

children.full: Grants individuals the right to defend themselves against libel or slander. Understood in the context of freedom of expression, this may not include prior censorship, allowing instead for legal remedy after the fact.
children.name: Right to protect one's reputation

children.full: Grants individuals whose religious or ethical beliefs prevent them from participating in war an exemption from military service.
children.name: Right to conscientious objection

children.full: Protection for individuals who are unable to repay loans or other financial obligations. The contractual rights of the lender are qualified by the right of the debtor to their freedom or dignity.
children.name: Rights of debtors

children.full: Recognizes secular marriages performed by a government official or other so empowered individuals, or religious marriages that also involve a license from the state.
children.name: Provision for civil marriage

children.full: Grants citizens the right to overthrow the government under certain circumstances. This right is usually expressed in terms of defending the constitutional order, rather than establishing a new one.
children.name: Right to overthrow government

children.full: Grants individuals the right to possess firearms and other weapons. This right may in some jurisdictions still be subject to regulation of the kinds of weapons that can be possessed, and the places and manners in which they may be transported.
children.name: Right to bear arms

children.full: Imposes a duty on the state or on the people to protect or conserve the environment. This may also accord to citizens the right to enjoy a healthy environment.
children.name: Protection of environment

children.full: Grants individuals the right to form and join trade unions or professional associations. This is an explicit right that goes beyond freedom of association.
children.name: Right to join trade unions

children.full: Gives citizens a general right to work, and/or obligates the state to provide work. This is distinct from the right to choose one's occupation.
children.name: Right to work

children.full: Obligates the state to provide health care to its citizens, or provides individuals with the general right to health care.  In some cases, health care must be provided by the government free of charge.
children.name: Right to health care

children.full: Requires the state to provide education free of charge. This may be limited at a certain age or level of educational attainment.
children.name: Free education

children.full: Obligates the state to provide financial or material resources to persons with disabilities.
children.name: State support for the disabled

children.full: Obligates the state to provide financial or material resources to elderly persons.
children.name: State support for the elderly

children.full: Requires children to attend school. This may be a requirement up to a certain age, or to a certain level of educational attainment.
children.name: Compulsory education

children.full: Obligates the state to provide financial or material resources to children.
children.name: State support for children

children.full: Commits the government to seeking the well-being of the society as a whole. May, but does not necessarily, refer to a national pension scheme.
children.name: General guarantee of social security

children.full: Prohibits employers from paying their employees at differing rates for the same work. A right to just remuneration.
children.name: Right to equal pay for work

children.full: Grants individuals and groups the right to cease work for a period of time, in an effort to exert pressure on their employer. This may or may not include protection for the jobs of strikers.
children.name: Right to strike

children.full: Grants individuals the right to a standard of living in concordance with a basic understanding of human dignity. May also refer to adequate well-being, suitable existence, or life worthy of a human being.
children.name: Right to reasonable standard of living

children.full: Grants individuals the right to work in environment free of preventable hazards. This may include an obligation on the state to provide safe working conditions.
children.name: Right to safe work environment

children.full: Grants individuals the right to vacations, weekly holidays, and/or annual paid vacation.
children.name: Right to rest and leisure

children.full: Protects children against exploitation in the workplace. This may be in the form of a ban on child workers, or as a requirement for additional protections for child workers.
children.name: Limits in the employment of children

children.full: Guarantees individuals equal access to higher education. In some cases this may be limited on a competitive basis, or by tests of aptitude.
children.name: Access to higher education

children.full: Obligates the state to provide financial or material resources to unemployed persons.
children.name: State support for the unemployed

children.full: Accords individuals the right to enjoy the benefits of scientific progress, or obligates the state to promote scientific advancement for the benefit of society.
children.name: Right to enjoy the benefits of science

children.full: A duty to serve a specified period of time in the country's military. Often also includes protections for conscientious objectors.
children.name: Duty to serve in the military

children.full: Requires all citizens to contribute to the expenses of the state through taxes. This is usually a general statement and may still allow for variation on the basis of income.
children.name: Duty to pay taxes

children.full: Requires individuals to contribute to the betterment of their society through work. This is usually a general statement and may still allow for variation on the basis of disability, age or other factors.
children.name: Duty to work

children.full: Protects individuals from prosecution for acts that were not criminal at the time that they were committed, or from changes in the penalties for acts.
children.name: Protection from ex post facto laws

children.full: Requires that those adjudicating a criminal trial maintain the posture that the accused is "innocent until proven guilty." This places the burden of proof on the side of the prosecution in the trial.
children.name: Presumption of innocence in trials

children.full: Grants individuals charged with an offense the right to have their trial held in public.
children.name: Right to public trial

children.full: Protects individuals from being prosecuted for actions that were not crimes at the time they were committed. Similarly, the sentence imposed cannot be greater than the one that was mandated at the time that the crime was committed.
children.name: Principle of no punishment without law

children.full: Gives individuals the right to appeal a judicial decision in a higher court if they are not satisfied with the outcome in the court of first instance. Does not necessarily require the appellate court to hear the case, but the mention of an appellate court may imply the power to appeal.
children.name: Right to appeal judicial decisions

children.full: Prohibits the state from charging an individual with an offense for which they have already been acquitted. This does not necessarily prevent the prosecution from appealing an acquittal.
children.name: Prohibition of double jeopardy

children.full: Grants an accused offender, and their legal counsel, the right to cross-examine evidence or witnesses brought against them by the prosecution.
children.name: Right to examine evidence/ witnesses

children.full: Grants individuals who have been arrested and charged with a crime the right to be released from custody until the time of their trial. This may require paying the court a sum of money to be repaid at the time of the trial, or other conditions for release.
children.name: Right to pre-trial release

children.full: Grants individuals the right to trial by jury, or more generally provides for citizen participation in the adjudication of guilt in criminal trials.
children.name: Jury trials required

children.full: Grants juveniles charged with crimes special protections in the judicial system. This may include special courts, different sentencing rules, or special detention centers.
children.name: Privileges for juveniles in criminal process

children.full: Grants the victims of crime rights in the justice process. These rights may include attendance at the trial, an opportunity to speak at the trial, restitution, or other measures to address the needs of crime victims.
children.name: Protection of victim's rights

children.full: Gives citizens the right to request judicial review of government actions or judgments that they believe have violated their rights.
children.name: Right to amparo

children.full: Requires that the state produce a public registry of the names of those imprisoned. This often serves as a check on arbitrary or unjust imprisonment.
children.name: Prison registry

children.full: Requires citizens or public officers to obey the constitution. This primarily applies to individuals in cases where the constitution includes a statement of the duties of citizens or holders of public office.
children.name: Duty to obey the constitution

children.full: Establishes whether or not the rights listed in the constitution are binding on private individuals as well as the state.
children.name: Binding effect of const rights

children.full: Rights that are understood to be unassailable, either because they are fundamental or “natural.”  In some countries, they may be absolute rights, not subject even to qualification.
children.name: Inalienable rights

children.full: A public official tasked with investigating improper or illegal actions on the part of government agencies which may infringe on the rights of individuals. Enables individuals to bring complaints about the actions of the government.
children.name: Ombudsman

children.full: Gives citizens the right to request judicial review of government actions or judgments that they believe have violated their rights.
children.name: Right to amparo

children.full: Guarantees that all individuals are entitled to the same privileges and immunities. Prohibits favoritism or discrimination to any group. All are considered to be equal before the law.
children.name: General guarantee of equality

children.full: Requires that everyone is treated equally before the law, without regard to their gender or sex. This may apply to both public and private interactions in some jurisdictions.
children.name: Equality regardless of gender

children.full: Requires that everyone is treated equally before the law, without regard to their race. This may apply to both public and private interactions in some jurisdictions.
children.name: Equality regardless of race

children.full: Requires that everyone is treated equally before the law, without regard to their religion. This may apply to both public and private interactions in some jurisdictions.
children.name: Equality regardless of religion

children.full: Requires that everyone is treated equally before the law, without regard to their country or place of origin. This may apply to both public and private interactions in some jurisdictions.
children.name: Equality regardless of origin

children.full: Requires that everyone is treated equally before the law, without regard to their creed, belief, or opinions. This may apply to both public and private interactions in some jurisdictions.
children.name: Equality regardless of creed or belief

children.full: Requires the state to offer its protection to one or more of the following vulnerable groups: stateless persons, asylum seekers, or refugees.
children.name: Protection of stateless persons

children.full: Requires that everyone is treated equally before the law, without regard to their political party membership or political opinions. This may apply to both public and private interactions in some jurisdictions.
children.name: Equality regardless of political party

children.full: Requires that everyone is treated equally before the law, without regard to their language. This may apply to both public and private interactions in some jurisdictions.
children.name: Equality regardless of language

children.full: Requires that everyone is treated equally before the law, without regard to their skin color. This may apply to both public and private interactions in some jurisdictions.
children.name: Equality regardless of skin color

children.full: Gives both spouses the same rights in marriage and family law. This is a separate issue from the general guarantee of gender equality.
children.name: Provision for matrimonial equality

children.full: Explicit references to social class. This may be in the context of either outlawing or providing for a system of social classes within the state, or in the context of pursuing socio-economic equality.
children.name: Mentions of social class

children.full: Requires that everyone is treated equally before the law, without regard to their parentage or birth. This may apply to both public and private interactions in some jurisdictions.
children.name: Equality regardless of parentage

children.full: Establishes a group right to self determination. This may be a reference to the nation as a whole, to groups in other countries, or to a portion of the state's population.
children.name: Right to self determination

children.full: Requires that everyone is treated equally before the law, without regard to any disability. This may apply to both public and private interactions in some jurisdictions.
children.name: Equality for persons with disabilities

children.full: Requires that everyone is treated equally before the law, without regard to their nationality. This may apply to both public and private interactions in some jurisdictions.
children.name: Equality regardless of nationality

children.full: Explains circumstances under which the rights of some individuals or groups may be restricted.
children.name: Restrictions on rights of groups

children.full: Requires that everyone is treated equally before the law, without regard to their age. This may apply to both public and private interactions in some jurisdictions.
children.name: Equality regardless of age

children.full: Requires that everyone is treated equally before the law, without regard to their tribe or clan. This may apply to both public and private interactions in some jurisdictions.
children.name: Equality regardless of tribe or clan

children.full: Grants indigenous peoples limited rights to self-government, particularly with regard to issues that affect their territory.
children.name: Indigenous right to self governance

children.full: Grants indigenous peoples the right to representation in the central government. This might, for example, involve a seat quota in the legislature.
children.name: Indigenous right to representation

children.full: Requires that everyone is treated equally before the law, without regard to their sexual orientation. This may apply to both public and private interactions in some jurisdictions.
children.name: Equality regardless of sexual orientation

children.full: Clarifies the citizenship status of members of indigenous groups. In some cases indigenous groups may be granted citizenship in a sub-national unit.
children.name: Citizenship of indigenous groups

children.full: Specifically grants indigenous peoples the right to vote in national elections or referenda.
children.name: Indigenous right to vote

children.full: Grants indigenous peoples an exemption from taxation by the central government.
children.name: Indigenous right not to pay taxes

children.full: Establishes the organs of municipal or local government, and their competencies.
children.name: Municipal government

children.full: Specifies the competencies of the governments of the subsidiary units in a federal system.
children.name: Subsidiary unit government

children.full: Establishes which level of government has supremacy in cases where their laws conflict.
children.name: National vs subnational laws

children.full: In federal countries, the power of the federal government to review legislation passed by the governments of the subnational units. Such review could be undertaken by a federal court or another part of the federal government.
children.name: Federal review of subnational legislation

children.full: Allows the state to incorporate new territory into the country. Usually also specifies the necessary steps for this to happen.
children.name: Accession of territory

children.full: Addresses secession or withdrawal of groups or territories of the state. In cases where secession is allowed, usually also specifies the legal process that must take place.
children.name: Secession of territory

children.full: Even where voting is considered to be a universal right, there may be some qualifications. For example, restrictions on the basis of residency, age, or criminal convictions are common.
children.name: Restrictions on voting

children.full: The right to vote is held by all citizens. There may nevertheless be some restrictions on voting by residency, age, residency or criminal conviction.
children.name: Claim of universal suffrage

children.full: Specifically grants indigenous peoples the right to vote in national elections or referenda.
children.name: Indigenous right to vote

children.full: Voting takes place in such a way that a citizen completes the ballot privately, and the ballot cannot be connected to the voter.
children.name: Secret ballot

children.full: When elections shall be held. This could be described in terms of a particular day, an interval between elections, or with relation to the dismissal of the legislature or executive.
children.name: Scheduling of elections

children.full: Describes characteristics, or rules for the establishment, of electoral districts. Constitutions rarely directly establish the districts, but rather describe where and how these decisions will be made.
children.name: Electoral districts

children.full: Rules that political parties and candidates must follow in financing electoral campaigns. Some constitutions establish government assistance for such purposes, or forbid receipt of funds from certain other sources.
children.name: Campaign financing

children.full: Establishes the boundaries of acceptable activity, or the organizational structure, of political parties. For example, parties may be bound to respect some fundamental principles of the state.
children.name: Restrictions on political parties

children.full: Requires that everyone is treated equally before the law, without regard to their political party membership or political opinions. This may apply to both public and private interactions in some jurisdictions.
children.name: Equality regardless of political party

children.full: Certain political parties, or parties with particular ideologies or characteristics, are prohibited. For example, some constitutions prohibit parties that are founded on a tribal or group identity.
children.name: Prohibited political parties

children.full: Describes which branch or body of the government has the power to regulate political parties, particularly those tasked with determining the unconstitutionality of certain parties.
children.name: Regulation of political parties

children.full: A particular political party, or type of party, has a special status within the state.
children.name: Preferred political parties

children.full: An independent commission responsible for facilitating and regulating elections. May be responsible for monitoring political parties and the financing of elections.
children.name: Electoral commission

children.full: Establishes the competencies of the electoral court. In addition to hearing challenges of election results, the court may be responsible for certifying various aspects of elections, including voter rolls and final vote tallies.
children.name: Electoral court powers

children.full: The procedure through which a candidate for an electoral court judgeship is nominated and approved.  This might involve approval from the executive, and all or part of the legislature.
children.name: Electoral court selection

children.full: The number of years that an electoral judge serves before either reappointment or dismissal is required.
children.name: Electoral court term length

children.full: The minimum age that an individual must have attained before assuming the office of judge in the electoral court.
children.name: Minimum age of electoral court judges

children.full: In cases where a judge has committed a crime, or otherwise compromised the integrity of their office, he or she may be removed from office. This may be carried out by the legislature, the executive, or another competent body.
children.name: Electoral court removal

children.full: The number of terms, either consecutive or in total, that an individual may serve as a judge in an electoral court.
children.name: Electoral court term limits

children.full: Grants individuals the right to hold religious beliefs, and to freely practice those religious beliefs. This right is also commonly understood to include the right to change one's religion, or to have no religion at all.
children.name: Freedom of religion

children.full: Requires that everyone is treated equally before the law, without regard to their religion. This may apply to both public and private interactions in some jurisdictions.
children.name: Equality regardless of religion

children.full: An invocation of the divine. Often found in the preamble, particularly in states with an established religion.
children.name: God or other deities

children.full: Establishment of an official religion, or religions, for the state. Other constitutions provide special treatment for certain religions, or conversely, expressly forbid the state from establishing an official religion.
children.name: Official religion

children.full: Requires that everyone is treated equally before the law, without regard to their creed, belief, or opinions. This may apply to both public and private interactions in some jurisdictions.
children.name: Equality regardless of creed or belief

children.full: Courts with limited jurisdiction to adjudicate matters arising in religious law. Jurisdiction may be limited on a confessional basis.
children.name: Establishment of religious courts

children.full: Religious organizations are granted a special status with regard to taxation. This may include exemptions from regular taxation of income or property.
children.name: Tax status of religious organizations

children.full: Protects the right of individuals to use their native language, or otherwise provides general protections for particular languages. Protected languages may be specified, but remain distinct from the official languages of the state.
children.name: Protection of language use

children.full: Requires that everyone is treated equally before the law, without regard to their language. This may apply to both public and private interactions in some jurisdictions.
children.name: Equality regardless of language

children.full: Requires that everyone is treated equally before the law, without regard to their race. This may apply to both public and private interactions in some jurisdictions.
children.name: Equality regardless of race

children.full: Minority ethnic communities are enabled to participate in the affairs of the state or society. Some constitutions offer additional protection against forced assimilation.
children.name: Integration of ethnic communities

children.full: Requires that everyone is treated equally before the law, without regard to their tribe or clan. This may apply to both public and private interactions in some jurisdictions.
children.name: Equality regardless of tribe or clan

children.full: Details the requirements for an individual to be granted citizenship at birth. The requirements may relate to the citizenship or residency of one or both parents, or to the location of an individual's birth.
children.name: Requirements for birthright citizenship

children.full: Requires that everyone is treated equally before the law, without regard to their country or place of origin. This may apply to both public and private interactions in some jurisdictions.
children.name: Equality regardless of origin

children.full: In extraordinary circumstances, usually relating to criminal convictions abroad, some constitutions give the government the power to deport citizens. In other constitutions, the government is specifically prohibited from deporting citizens but allows deportation of other residents.
children.name: Power to deport citizens

children.full: Primarily concerned with the movements of foreign nationals, describes the powers of the government to restrict entry into or exit out of the state.
children.name: Restrictions on entry or exit

children.full: Requires that everyone is treated equally before the law, without regard to their nationality. This may apply to both public and private interactions in some jurisdictions.
children.name: Equality regardless of nationality

children.full: Clarifies the citizenship status of members of indigenous groups. In some cases indigenous groups may be granted citizenship in a sub-national unit.
children.name: Citizenship of indigenous groups

children.full: Grants indigenous peoples limited rights to self-government, particularly with regard to issues that affect their territory.
children.name: Indigenous right to self governance

children.full: Grants indigenous peoples the right to representation in the central government. This might, for example, involve a seat quota in the legislature.
children.name: Indigenous right to representation

children.full: Clarifies the citizenship status of members of indigenous groups. In some cases indigenous groups may be granted citizenship in a sub-national unit.
children.name: Citizenship of indigenous groups

children.full: Specifically grants indigenous peoples the right to vote in national elections or referenda.
children.name: Indigenous right to vote

children.full: Grants indigenous peoples an exemption from taxation by the central government.
children.name: Indigenous right not to pay taxes

children.full: An explicit declaration that judges are autonomous or the judiciary as a whole is independent. This may include protection from outside influence on their decision making, particularly from other branches of the government.
children.name: Judicial independence

children.full: Procedures for examining whether the content of a piece of legislation is in accord with the constitution. This may or may not be permissible prior to the promulgation of the legislation.
children.name: Constitutionality of legislation

children.full: In cases where a judge has committed a crime, or otherwise compromised the integrity of their office, he or she may be removed from office. This may be carried out by the legislature, the executive, or another competent body.
children.name: Supreme/ordinary court judge removal

children.full: Establishes the competencies of the supreme court, other than adjudication and review of legislation. Such powers may include supervision of elections, impeachment of the executive, review of treaties, or other specified functions.
children.name: Supreme court powers

children.full: Establishes the competencies of the constitutional court, other than adjudication and review of legislation. Such powers may include supervision of elections, impeachment of the executive, review of treaties, or other specified functions.
children.name: Constitutional court powers

children.full: Prevents tampering with the salaries of judges for political ends. Can bolster judicial independence.  Provisions about protection of the overall judicial budget are included here.
children.name: Protection of judges' salaries

children.full: A requirement that judges must at least take into account, and potentially follow, precedents set by rulings in higher courts.
children.name: Judicial precedence

children.full: The procedure through which a candidate for a supreme court judgeship is nominated and approved.  This might involve approval from the executive, and all or part of the legislature.
children.name: Supreme court selection

children.full: Establishes the competencies of the supreme court, other than adjudication and review of legislation. Such powers may include supervision of elections, impeachment of the executive, review of treaties, or other specified functions.
children.name: Supreme court powers

children.full: Qualifications that an individual must meet in order to serve as a judge on the supreme court. These often concern educational and professional credentials.
children.name: Eligibility for supreme court judges

children.full: The number of years that a supreme court justice serves before either reappointment or dismissal is required.
children.name: Supreme court term length

children.full: The minimum age that an individual must have attained before assuming the office of judge on the supreme court.
children.name: Minimum age of supreme court judges

children.full: The number of terms, either consecutive or in total, that an individual may serve as a judge on the supreme court.
children.name: Supreme court term limits

children.full: Procedures for examining whether the content of a piece of legislation is in accord with the constitution. This may or may not be permissible prior to the promulgation of the legislation.
children.name: Constitutionality of legislation

children.full: Protects individuals from the use of excess power by administrative agencies of the government. Commonly also establishes procedures for review of such actions and provides redress for those harmed.
children.name: Ultra-vires administrative actions

children.full: Gives citizens the right to request judicial review of government actions or judgments that they believe have violated their rights.
children.name: Right to amparo

children.full: Establishes the basic organization of the judicial branch. In some cases only the highest court is established, leaving further organization to be determined by ordinary legislation.
children.name: Structure of the courts

children.full: Establishes a special body to monitor judges. Judicial councils are commonly tasked with reviewing complaints about judges, and are sometimes involved in selecting, promoting, and removing judges.
children.name: Establishment of judicial council

children.full: A court that is especially empowered to interpret the constitution, and usually to rule on whether legislation is in accord with the principles of the constitution.
children.name: Establishment of constitutional court

children.full: Courts with jurisdiction limited to charges against members of the military, and tasked with enforcing military law.
children.name: Establishment of military courts

children.full: Courts that adjudicate disputes about the government's exercise of power in ordinary administrative functions.
children.name: Establishment of administrative courts

children.full: Special courts that are empowered to review the actions of public servants acting in their official capacity.
children.name: Courts for judging public officials

children.full: Courts with limited jurisdiction to adjudicate disputes between individuals or trade unions and businesses.
children.name: Establishment of labor courts

children.full: Courts with limited jurisdiction to adjudicate matters arising in religious law. Jurisdiction may be limited on a confessional basis.
children.name: Establishment of religious courts

children.full: Courts with limited jurisdiction to adjudicate disputes between individuals or businesses and the state with regard to taxation.
children.name: Establishment of tax courts

children.full: A court that is especially empowered to interpret the constitution, and usually to rule on whether legislation is in accord with the principles of the constitution.
children.name: Establishment of constitutional court

children.full: The procedure through which a candidate for a constitutional court judgeship is nominated and approved.  This might involve approval from the executive, and all or part of the legislature.
children.name: Constitutional court selection

children.full: Establishes the competencies of the constitutional court, other than adjudication and review of legislation. Such powers may include supervision of elections, impeachment of the executive, review of treaties, or other specified functions.
children.name: Constitutional court powers

children.full: Qualifications that an individual must meet in order to serve as a judge in a constitutional court. These often concern educational and professional credentials.
children.name: Eligibility for const court judges

children.full: The number of terms, either consecutive or in total, that an individual may serve as a judge in a constitutional court.
children.name: Constitutional court term limits

children.full: The minimum age that an individual must have attained before assuming the office of judge in a constitutional court.
children.name: Min age of const court judges

children.full: Determines procedures for, or treatment of, judicial opinions handed down by the constitutional court.
children.name: Constitutional court opinions

children.full: Qualifications that an individual must meet in order to serve as a judge in an ordinary court. These often concern educational and professional credentials.
children.name: Eligibility for ordinary court judges

children.full: The number of years that an ordinary court judge serves before either reappointment or dismissal is required.
children.name: Ordinary court term length

children.full: The minimum age that an individual must have attained before assuming the office of judge in an ordinary court.
children.name: Minimum age of ordinary court judges

children.full: The number of terms, either consecutive or in total, that an individual may serve as a judge in an ordinary court.
children.name: Ordinary court term limits

children.full: Protects individuals from the use of excess power by administrative agencies of the government. Commonly also establishes procedures for review of such actions and provides redress for those harmed.
children.name: Ultra-vires administrative actions

children.full: Courts that adjudicate disputes about the government's exercise of power in ordinary administrative functions.
children.name: Establishment of administrative courts

children.full: The procedure through which a candidate for an administrative judgeship is nominated and approved. This might involve approval from the executive, and all or part of the legislature.
children.name: Administrative court selection

children.full: Conditions that an individual must fulfil in order to serve as a judge in an administrative court. These often concern educational and professional credentials.
children.name: Eligibility for administrative  judges

children.full: The number of years that an administrative judge serves before either reappointment or dismissal is required.
children.name: Administrative court term length

children.full: The minimum age that an individual must have attained before assuming the office of judge in an administrative court.
children.name: Min age of administrative judges

children.full: The number of terms, either consecutive or in total, that an individual may serve as a judge in an administrative court.
children.name: Administrative court term limits

children.full: Establishes the competencies of the electoral court. In addition to hearing challenges of election results, the court may be responsible for certifying various aspects of elections, including voter rolls and final vote tallies.
children.name: Electoral court powers

children.full: The procedure through which a candidate for an electoral court judgeship is nominated and approved.  This might involve approval from the executive, and all or part of the legislature.
children.name: Electoral court selection

children.full: The number of years that an electoral judge serves before either reappointment or dismissal is required.
children.name: Electoral court term length

children.full: The minimum age that an individual must have attained before assuming the office of judge in the electoral court.
children.name: Minimum age of electoral court judges

children.full: In cases where a judge has committed a crime, or otherwise compromised the integrity of their office, he or she may be removed from office. This may be carried out by the legislature, the executive, or another competent body.
children.name: Electoral court removal

children.full: The number of terms, either consecutive or in total, that an individual may serve as a judge in an electoral court.
children.name: Electoral court term limits

children.full: Establishes a special body to monitor judges. Judicial councils are commonly tasked with reviewing complaints about judges, and are sometimes involved in selecting, promoting, and removing judges.
children.name: Establishment of judicial council

children.full: An independent commission responsible for facilitating and regulating elections. May be responsible for monitoring political parties and the financing of elections.
children.name: Electoral commission

children.full: Establishes or affirms a central bank. May also include requirements for its governance and operations.
children.name: Central bank

children.full: A public official tasked with investigating improper or illegal actions on the part of government agencies which may infringe on the rights of individuals. Enables individuals to bring complaints about the actions of the government.
children.name: Ombudsman

children.full: Establishes a commission to regulate mass media. This may include ensuring free expression, and in some cases enforcing some form of censorship.
children.name: Media commission

children.full: An independent commission specifically empowered to investigate corruption within the government.
children.name: Counter corruption commission

children.full: Reference to wired or wireless communication, and the industries that support it, usually in the context of regulation. Includes telephones, satellites, the internet, and other communication technologies.
children.name: Telecommunications

children.full: Reference to the wireless transmission of audio-visual programs, usually in the context of regulation.
children.name: Television

children.full: Reference to the wireless transmission of audio programs, usually in the context of regulation.
children.name: Radio

children.full: Describes the relationship between the state and the media. This may give the state control over all media, allow the state to operate some media, or prohibit the state from such activities.
children.name: State operation of the media

children.full: Establishes a commission to regulate mass media. This may include ensuring free expression, and in some cases enforcing some form of censorship.
children.name: Media commission

children.name: Electoral commission

children.name: Regulation of political parties

children.name: Electoral court term length
